3 muA deuteron beam of 52 MeV and 2.5
mm diameter incident on an internal target.
Beam current was registered by a
calibrated current-to-frequency converter. It was
corrected for the effect of deuterons absorption in
the steel target entrance wall assuming that only (85
+/- 5) % of the beam deuterons have reached the
lithium.
Metallic natural lithium of 21.8 mm thickness was
enclosed in a stainless steel container (the drawing
of the target is available in reference). The
upstream 1.1 mm thick side of container takes away 12
MeV. Target was positioned inside the cyclotron
magnet gap and was cooled by water. A separate
measurement with empty steel container was made to
subtract the neutron background.
The measured data were corrected for the H-3 decay
and for the neutron background produced in the steel
container wall of the Li target.
The tritiated water was analyzed for the
amount of tritium in an automated liquid
scintillation system Beckman Instruments LS 6000TA.
The 7% uncertainty derives from the
scatter (5%) of H-3 measurements with two targets and
correction for the target wall thickness.
The tritium in the irradiated lithium target
was measured by releasing it from the target at
several hundred degrees Celsius within a quartz tube
through which a gas stream of 95% Ar + 5% H2 was
flowing at 50 ml/min. The gas was subsequently
oxidized in passing through a CuO bed. The resulting
H2O+HTO gas was absorbed in a molecular sieve. The
molecular sieve was periodically changed and eluted
with water.
Text (p.16) of FZKA-6764.
The measured data were corrected for decay and for
the neutron background produced in the steel target
wall, as well as for the gamma ray absorption in the
steel wall and in the lithium by about 8%.
The gamma spectrometer was positioned at
distance 65 cm from irradiated sample and was
protected by a lead collimator in its front to
reduce the counting efficiency. Spectrometer was
calibrated with Eu-152 g-ray source.
The 12% uncertainty derives from the
scatter of several Be-7 and calibration measurements
and the uncertainties of the corrections.
The Be-7 yield was determined by
measuring the 478 keV g-ray line from the irradiated
target with a g-ray spectrometer. It was done after a
cooling time of about 100 days, but prior to
destroying the target for the tritium measurement.
